item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese State Broadcaster Gets Its American Rices Confused
item.description: China Central Television used images of Condoleezza Rice in a report about a Beijing visit by Susan E. Rice, President Obama’s national security adviser.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ng Han Guan
item.media:description: Susan Rice with China's state councilor, Yang Jiechi, in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Obama Ready to Authorize Airstrikes on ISIS in Syria
item.description: The decision would take the military campaign against the Sunni militant group into new and unpredictable terrain.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: President Obama with congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday, where he briefed them on his plans for combating the Sunni militant group ISIS.

item.title: Cheney Urges House G.O.P. to Abandon Isolationism
item.description: Before President Obama’s address on ISIS, former Vice President Dick Cheney urged House Republicans to embrace a strong military and try to stop the establishment of a terrorist state in the Middle East.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN

item.title: Blast Decimates Leadership of Syrian Rebel Group
item.description: An explosion tore through a meeting of Ahrar al-Sham on Tuesday, killing a dozen of its leaders and striking a blow against the forces seeking to topple President Bashar al-Assad.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Ex-President’s Son Wounded in Tense Battle
item.description: Nigerian ground forces backed by warplanes battled Boko Haram militants on Tuesday in a second day of heavy fighting that wounded the son of former President Olusegun Obasanjo, a senior official said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Gaza: Arrests Suggest Disagreement on Truce Details
item.description: The Israeli military arrested four fishermen early Tuesday in what Palestinian officials said was a violation of the cease-fire agreement signed last month.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: 24 Killed When Mosque Roof Collapses
item.description: At least 24 people were killed and seven injured when the roof of a mosque in the eastern city of Lahore collapsed Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI

item.title: Longtime Rivals Look to Team Up to Confront ISIS
item.description: As the United States and its allies look to fight the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, an unlikely collection of longtime adversaries are scrambling to see if they can cooperate to defeat the rising threat.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Kurdish pesh merga fighters on Tuesday battled ISIS at a point east of Mosul secured with the help of United States airstrikes.

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Troops Fend Off Militant Attack in Karachi
item.description: The Pakistani Navy said it repelled a terrorist attack over the weekend after a six-hour exchange of fire at a naval dockyard in the southern port city of Karachi.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Blast Decimates Leadership of Rebel Group
item.description: An explosion tore through a secret meeting of one of Syria’s strongest rebel groups on Tuesday, killing a dozen of its top leaders, including its head, Hassan Abboud.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Violence Erupts in Yemen Capital After Weeks of Rallies
item.description: Pro-government forces in the capital opened fire on Tuesday at thousands of demonstrators from the Shiite religious minority, killing six and injuring dozens, officials and witnesses said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By SAEED AL BATATI
item.media:description: Shiite supporters of a rebel group, the Houthis, helped a fellow protester on Tuesday near the cabinet offices in the capital, Sana.

item.title: Military Memo: Amid Intensifying Requests, American Military Aid to Ukraine Stalls
item.description: Despite appeals from the Ukrainian armed forces, the United States has provided only a modest package of nonlethal assistance to the government in Kiev, and much of it has yet to arrive.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Fiji Government Says Its Golan Heights Peacekeepers Will Be Released Soon
item.description: The country’s 45-member United Nations peacekeeping contingent in the Golan Heights was seized by the Syrian branch of Al Qaeda nearly two weeks ago.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Canada Chases Down an Arctic Mystery, and Some See a Political Strategy
item.description: Canadian researchers say they have located a ship from Sir John Franklin’s disastrous expedition in the 1840s to map the Northwest Passage, an area of new international interest as Arctic ice retreats.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: A ship from Sir John Franklin’s Northwest Passage expedition has been located.

item.title: Ukraine Town Bears Scars of Russian Offensive That Turned Tide in Conflict
item.description: Days after the Russian artillery units’ assault, Ukraine agreed to a cease-fire cementing the rebels’ hold on its southeast region.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: After Russian units bombarded Ukraine forces around Ilovaisk, a Ukrainian soldier’s helmet marked his grave.

item.title: Iran’s Talks With Russia May Strike at Sanctions
item.description: The Iranian negotiator at nuclear talks said his country would not countenance any new economic penalties imposed by the United States.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Moving Argentina’s Capital From Buenos Aires Could Make Things Worse
item.description: Moving a government to an isolated spot, as Argentina may do, can mean more corruption.
item.dc:creator: By FILIPE R. CAMPANTE

item.title: The Push to Keep Scotland in the Fold
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron and his counterparts announced that they would fly north to campaign against dismemberment of the union with England.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Ruth Cheadle, a bride-to-be from California, waiting to be married in Edinburgh, Scotland, shows her support for Scotland's independence campaign.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Russia’s Next Land Grab
item.description: The Putin playbook — stir up trouble so you can send in “peacekeepers” — is on view in the Caucasus.
item.dc:creator: By BRENDA SHAFFER

item.title: New Emblem of an Elemental Conflict: Seized West Bank Land
item.description: Israel’s appropriation of nearly 1,000 acres of Palestinian territory has again illustrated the distance between the Israelis and the Palestinians months after the breakdown of American-brokered talks.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Open Source: Aides to Ayatollah Khamenei Tweet From His Hospital Room
item.description: Updates from the bedside of Iran’s supreme leader during his recovery from prostate surgery may have been intended to preempt rumors about his health.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: A Question of Identity: Why Does Scotland Want Independence? It’s Culture vs. Economics
item.description: The debate over Scottish independence sheds light on the nature of the state, and what citizens expect from their nation.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL IRWIN
item.media:description: Alex Salmond, Scotland's first minister (front center, with large sign), and other supporters of independence in Edinburgh on Tuesday.

item.title: Before Pearl Harbor, Emperor Warned Against War
item.description: Emperor Hirohito said attacking the United States was “self-destructive,” an official history of his reign says.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Emperor Hirohito of Japan, shown in 1937, warned against war with the United States but did little to prevent it, according to an official history of his reign released on Tuesday.

item.title: Ebola Cases Reported Up Sharply in Liberia
item.description: The World Health Organization said the number of new patients in Liberia pointed to “a large but previously invisible caseload.”
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A burial team in Monrovia, Liberia, on Sept. 6 collected the body of a man believed to have died from Ebola. Their workload has grown quickly in recent weeks.

item.title: Libyan Refugees Stream to Tunisia for Care, and Tell of a Home That Is Torn Apart
item.description: A new surge of refugees has arrived in Tunisia as fighting has spread to the Libyan capital, Tripoli. Their accounts depict a country spiraling into chaos.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
